title: 103_hr4116
content: The "Senior Safe Corridors Act" aims to establish safety programs for senior citizens in high-crime areas through grant programs under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The Senior Safe Corridors Act authorizes grants to fund safety programs for senior citizens in high-density areas to reduce violent crimes against them by increasing police presence and community watchfulness, including escorting services. To apply for a grant under the Senior Safe Corridors Act, a State or local government with over 100,000 residents must submit an application to the Director with required information. The Director will approve or disapprove applications within 60 days. To receive a grant under the Senior Safe Corridors Act, an applicant must demonstrate significant violent crime against senior citizens in affected areas, state the number of seniors served, involve various community sectors in the program, and meet any additional requirements. The Director will determine grant recipients based on specified criteria, giving priority to applicants with the most community involvement. The grant amount cannot exceed 75% of total program costs, with a waiver option for local governments facing financial difficulties. Grant recipients must submit reports as required. "Grant recipients must submit annual reports containing program information and evaluation of impact on senior citizen crime. Funds can be used for report compilation. Definitions are provided in Section 1706." "Definitions for grant application purposes include terms like 'applicant,' 'Director,' 'high-density senior citizen area,' and 'program.' Authorization of appropriations is outlined in Section 4." Section 4 authorizes appropriations of $50,000,000 for fiscal year 1995 and additional funds for fiscal years 1996 through 1998 to carry out part Q. Section 5 includes technical and conforming amendments. Section 5 makes technical and conforming amendments to the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, including changes related to programs for establishing safe corridors for senior citizens. Part Q of the legislation authorizes grants for safe corridors for senior citizens, with specific sections outlining grant authorization, applications, criteria, grant limits, reports by recipients, and definitions. Part R addresses the transition, effective date, and repealer of rules and authorities.
